image.altText: A court sketch of Erin Patterson.

items.synopsis: Prosecutors say it will take months to analyse computer equipment seized from the home of a woman charged with murder over a mushroom meal linked to three deaths in Victoria's east.

title.children: Erin Patterson faces court after police lay murder charges over mushroom meal

image.altText: hayden turns to speak to his wife, who rests her hand on his arm

items.synopsis: The life and legacy of Labor giant Bill Hayden is being honoured at a state funeral service in his hometown south-west of Brisbane today. Watch live.

title.children: Political heavyweights, friends and family come together for Bill Hayden's state funeral

image.altText: A red stage with Qantas logo on projector

items.synopsis: Qantas is holding its AGM this morning, just a few days after the airline defended itself against so-called "ghost flight" allegations. Meanwhile, Australian Clinical Labs is facing a court case over a data hack last year. Read about it on our live blog.

title.children: Qantas faces shareholder revolt at its AGM after turbulent year, ASX jumps after Wall Street bounce

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Based on proxy votes cast ahead of today's AGM, Qantas CEO Vanessa Hudson has been appointed to the airline's board. Based on shareholders who cast their votes and didn't abstain, 99.2% of votes were cast in favour for her election. Doug Parker has also been elected to the Qantas vote, receiving just over 98% of votes in favour from shareholders.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Qantas CEO Vanessa Hudson appointed to board

children.content: Based on proxy votes cast ahead of today's AGM, Qantas CEO Vanessa Hudson has been appointed to the airline's board.
Based on shareholders who cast their votes and didn't abstain, 99.2% of votes were cast in favour for her election.
Doug Parker has also been elected to the Qantas vote, receiving just over 98% of votes in favour from shareholders.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: One shareholder has asked a question online about Prime Minister Anthony Albanese's teenage son being granted membership to the exclusive Qantas Chairman's Lounge. Mr Goyder simply replied he would not be making any comment on Chairman's Lounge memberships. Qantas also responded to another question that it was confident in KPMG auditing the business despite consultancy firms being under scrutiny.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'No comment' on prime minister's son being Chairman's Lounge member

children.content: One shareholder has asked a question online about Prime Minister Anthony Albanese's teenage son being granted membership to the exclusive Qantas Chairman's Lounge.
Mr Goyder simply replied he would not be making any comment on Chairman's Lounge memberships.
Qantas also responded to another question that it was confident in KPMG auditing the business despite consultancy firms being under scrutiny.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Two questions have been asked around regional flight availability and prices. "We understand it's a very important matter for our customers in regional towns," Mr Goyder says. Ms Hudson says Qantas focuses a lot on making sure regional airfares are as affordable as possible, but the cost of serving regional communities is a lot higher, largely because smaller aircraft consume large amounts of fuel for small amount of seats. Ms Hudson says Qantas is proud to serve regional communities. She says a specific question around the price of flights between Tamworth and Sydney would need to be looked at in closer detail and she would follow up with that shareholder who asked that question.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Questions on regional airfares being higher and flight availability

children.content: Two questions have been asked around regional flight availability and prices.
"We understand it's a very important matter for our customers in regional towns," Mr Goyder says.

Ms Hudson says Qantas focuses a lot on making sure regional airfares are as affordable as possible, but the cost of serving regional communities is a lot higher, largely because smaller aircraft consume large amounts of fuel for small amount of seats.
Ms Hudson says Qantas is proud to serve regional communities.
She says a specific question around the price of flights between Tamworth and Sydney would need to be looked at in closer detail and she would follow up with that shareholder who asked that question.

image.altText: Gaza strip

items.synopsis: Seven United Nations special rapporteurs issue a warning, but Israel says it is aiming its attacks at Hamas not civilians. Follow live.

title.children: UN experts warn Palestinians are at 'grave risk of genocide' as Israel says it is making advances

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Israeli opposition leader and former prime minister Yair Lapid has told ABC News Breakfast questions over concerns that people in Gaza are at risk of genocide should be directed at Hamas. As we reported earlier, seven United Nations special rapporteurs have warned that Palestinian people in Gaza are facing a “grave risk of genocide”. "We are worried as well, but the question should be directed at Hamas, not at us," Lapid said on ABC News Breakfast. "We didn't initiate this, we didn't want this war. "We are protecting our own people against a murderous terrorist organisation that is killing the innocent and we have no other choice. "Yes, I think the people of Gaza are in peril, the same as the people of Israel, we are all being threatened and killed by a terror organisation." The Hamas-run Palestinian health ministry estimates 9,061 people, including 3,760 children, have been killed in Gaza. Lapid said as Israel was fighting Hamas in a densely populated area there was "going to be casualities". "Of course we are sorry," he said. "We have no fight with babies, we have no fight with civilians. We are doing our best to avoid hurting the civilians, this is exactly the difference between a terror organisation and a law-abiding democratic country. "I am acknowledging the fact that the innocent are suffering and I am urging you to direct your questions about it to Hamas." The United Nations human rights office said on Wednesday that it was concerned that Israeli air strikes on Gaza's Jabalia refugee camp could amount to war crimes. When asked if Israel was heeding international concerns about the growing civilian death toll in Gaza, Lapid said "yes". "But I am not sure we need this because we are concerned to begin with," he said. "This is not something we want to do. "This is not a war we wanted to be engaged in, this was forced upon us. Part of the problem we have going into this war is that we want to do our best to avoid hurting the civilians. "Right now both Israelis and the people of Gaza are victims of Hamas." Watch the full interview from ABC News Breakfast below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Former Israeli PM says concerns over a risk of genocide should be directed to Hamas

children.content: Israeli opposition leader and former prime minister Yair Lapid has told ABC News Breakfast questions over concerns that people in Gaza are at risk of genocide should be directed at Hamas.
As we reported earlier, seven United Nations special rapporteurs have warned that
Palestinian people in Gaza are facing a “grave risk of genocide”.
"We are worried as well, but the question should be directed at Hamas, not at us," Lapid said on ABC News Breakfast.
"We didn't initiate this, we didn't want this war.
"We are protecting our own people against a murderous terrorist organisation that is killing the innocent and we have no other choice.
"Yes, I think the people of Gaza are in peril, the same as the people of Israel, we are all being threatened and killed by a terror organisation."
The Hamas-run Palestinian health ministry estimates 9,061 people, including 3,760 children, have been killed in Gaza.
Lapid said as Israel was fighting Hamas in a densely populated area there was "going to be casualities".
"Of course we are sorry," he said.

"We have no fight with babies, we have no fight with civilians. We are doing our best to avoid hurting the civilians, this is exactly the difference between a terror organisation and a law-abiding democratic country.
"I am acknowledging the fact that the innocent are suffering and I am urging you to direct your questions about it to Hamas."
The United Nations human rights office said on Wednesday that it was concerned that Israeli air strikes on Gaza's Jabalia refugee camp could amount to war crimes.
When asked if Israel was heeding international concerns about the growing civilian death toll in Gaza, Lapid said "yes".
"But I am not sure we need this because we are concerned to begin with," he said.
"This is not something we want to do.
"This is not a war we wanted to be engaged in, this was forced upon us. Part of the problem we have going into this war is that we want to do our best to avoid hurting the civilians.
"Right now both Israelis and the people of Gaza are victims of Hamas."
Watch the full interview from ABC News Breakfast below:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The leader of Hezbollah, Hassan Nasrallah, is set to deliver a speech — his first since the start of Israel-Gaza war — and everyone here in Israel is wondering what he'll say. To catch you up, Hezbollah is a militant Shia Muslim group and a major political party based in Lebanon. Like Hamas in Gaza, the group is backed by Iran, but it's way bigger, better trained, and more powerful. Hezbollah has been firing rockets across Lebanon's shared border with Israel, raising fears here that it could escalate into war with a far more formidable opponent. So with Nasrallah due to speak at 3pm Friday Jerusalem time (midnight Saturday AEDT), some people in the Middle East are nervous about what he's going to announce. Eyal Hulata, Israel's former national security advisor, says he's not expecting a declaration of war. "I have no intel but … I think he will use this opportunity to say he was always right, Israel is fragile, like a spiderweb, look how easy it was for Hamas to infiltrate," he said. "But I don't expect him to announce that he's going to escalate … I might be wrong, he does hold the keys to real escalation of the situation. If he decides to act differently, this can still inflame into a regional conflict."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Hezbollah's chief has a mysterious speech planned. What will he say?

children.content: The leader of Hezbollah, Hassan Nasrallah, is set to deliver a speech — his first since the start of Israel-Gaza war — and everyone here in Israel is wondering what he'll say.

props.alt: A man with a beard and glasses

children.content: Hassan Nasrallah is the chief of the militant Shia Muslim group and major political party based in Lebanon.
(Reuters: Aziz Taher)
To catch you up, Hezbollah is a militant Shia Muslim group and a major political party based in Lebanon.
Like Hamas in Gaza, the group is backed by
Iran, but it's way bigger, better trained, and more powerful.
Hezbollah has been firing rockets across Lebanon's shared border with Israel, raising fears here that it could escalate into war with a far more formidable opponent.
So with Nasrallah due to speak at 3pm Friday Jerusalem time (midnight Saturday AEDT), some people in the Middle East are nervous about what he's going to announce.
Eyal Hulata, Israel's former national security advisor, says he's not expecting a declaration of war.
"I have no intel but … I think he will use this opportunity to say he was always right, Israel is fragile, like a spiderweb, look how easy it was for Hamas to infiltrate," he said.

"But I don't expect him to announce that he's going to escalate … I might be wrong, he does hold the keys to real escalation of the situation. If he decides to act differently, this can still inflame into a regional conflict."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by ABC producer Chérine Yazbeck in Beirut On October 7, when Hamas-led militants launched their attack on Israel, Ghassan Abu Sittah was in London. The surgeon has a very successful practice in the UK. But when he saw the news, he immediately booked his flights and began his journey towards Gaza. The British-Palestinian doctor knew the attack would likely lead to a ground incursion of the coastal enclave. Fearing a crisis would befall Gaza's hospitals, he wanted to be there to treat patients with critical conditions. "I studied in London but did my internship during the conflict in Lebanon in 1996," he told the ABC. "I have a long experience of working in conflict zones — Iraq, Syria, Lebanon and Gaza." He says the health system in the region is falling apart, with patients sleeping in corridors. He also says conditions in the hospitals in Gaza are so bad he's resorted to using vinegar as disinfectant.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The London-based surgeon who flew to Gaza when war broke out to treat patients

children.content: Reporting by ABC producer Chérine Yazbeck in Beirut
On October 7, when Hamas-led militants launched their attack on Israel, Ghassan Abu Sittah was in London.
The surgeon has a very successful practice in the UK. But when he saw the news, he immediately booked his flights and began his journey towards Gaza.
Ghassan Abu Sittah left London for Gaza when war broke out.
(Supplied: Ghassan Abu Sitta)
The British-Palestinian doctor knew the attack would likely lead to a ground incursion of the coastal enclave.
Fearing a crisis would befall Gaza's hospitals, he wanted to be there to treat patients with critical conditions.
"I studied in London but did my internship during the conflict in Lebanon in 1996," he told the ABC.
"I have a long experience of working in conflict zones — Iraq, Syria, Lebanon and Gaza."
He says the health system in the region is falling apart, with patients sleeping in corridors.
He also says conditions in the hospitals in Gaza are so bad he's resorted to using vinegar as disinfectant.
